text:
There is no extension for application/sdp at IANA, but sdp is common.
SDP files are usefull for "One Click Streaming", the use of http://bla/bla.sdps is suggested in Ciscos MPEG4IP project and in the Dicas MPEGABLE broadcaster.
creator: uzs106@uni-bonn.de

text:
The policy is to only add IANA-approved MIME types to the shipped configuration;
please re-open when this gets an official assignment.
creator: jorton@redhat.com

text:
The pity is that the extension sdp may never get any status at IANA.
But SUNs application/vnd.stardivision.impress, not registered at IANA is spreading.
Notice, that the extension sdp is as common for application/sdp, which is registered at IANA (without an extension), as m3u is common for audio/x-mpegurl, which is not registered at IANA (neither MIME type, nor extension) and was included in mime.types (thanks for that again!)

application/sdp has not been as important as audio/x-mpegurl in the past, but it will become important in the future, since SDP is some sort of base of VoIP, ISMA MPEG Video streaming etc.
I would not care about it so much, for the authors of the RFCs it is just a theoretical problem, for me it was a practical problem. 

To add application/sdp sdp into mime.types would stop vendors of Linux distributions to add application/vnd.stardivision.impress sdp into mime.types, like the inclusion of audio/x-mpegurl m3u did stop them from adding audio/mpegurl m3u and similar nonsense.

I think somebody must care about such things, SUN did not, mime.types is much more important than IANA ;-)


Best, H.
creator: uzs106@uni-bonn.de

text:
Well, if there's a conflict, adding one mapping to the httpd mime.types does not
solve the problem, it just propagates it.  That's *exactly* the reason why we
defer to IANA for extension/MIME-type mappings.
creator: jorton@redhat.com
